case_name: Workmen v. Management of 11 Tea Estates

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 390 of 1963 was filed by special leave from the award of the Industrial Tribunal, Assam at Gauhati.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 390 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the award dated December 11, 1959, of the Industrial Tribunal, Assam at Gauhati in Reference No. 7 of 1959.

facts.text: Award dated December 11, 1959, by Industrial Tribunal, Assam at Gauhati in Reference No. 7 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the award dated December 11, 1959, of the Industrial Tribunal, Assam at Gauhati in Reference No. 7 of 1959. B. Agarwal, J.N. Hazarika and K.P. Gupta, for the appellants.

facts.text: Industrial dispute between the Management of 11 Tea Estates (respondents) and their workmen (appellants).

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave arises from an industrial dispute between the respondent, the Management of 11 Tea Estates and the appellants, their workmen.

facts.text: Lay-off declared by respondents in the 11 tea estates in February 1959, lasting 45 days.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the appellants raised a dispute against the respondent in regard to the lay-off declared by them in the estates in question in February, 1959. The said lay-off lasted for 45 days

facts.text: Appellants claimed full wages for the lay-off period, contending it was not justified.

anchor.surface_text: and the appellants contention was that the lay-off was not justified, and so, they were entitled to their full wages for the period of the lay-off.

facts.text: Respondents claimed lay-off justified, entitled to only section 25C compensation.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents Managing Agents for the nine Companies that run the 11 tea estates in question, resisted this claim on the ground that the lay-off was justified and they alleged that the appellants were not entitled to anything more than the compensation prescribed by section 25C of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947

facts.text: Dispute referred to Industrial Tribunal by Governor of Assam under s.10(1)(d) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: This dispute was referred to the adjudication of the Industrial Tribunal by the Governor of Assam under s. 10(1)(d) of the Act.

facts.text: 11 tea estates run by nine companies, Managing Agents M/s. Macneill and Barry Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that these 11 tea estates are run by nine Companies and M/s. Macneill and Barry Ltd. are the Managing Agents of all these companies.

facts.text: Tea estates situated in Cachar District.

anchor.surface_text: The case for the respondent was that the tea estates in question which are all situated in Cachar District had to face a long period of depression in trade

facts.text: Respondents faced financial depression due to poor tea prices in 1959.

anchor.surface_text: by reason of the poor prices generally commanded by the tea produced by them. In 1959, the management faced a very difficult financial position

facts.text: Tribunal held lay-off justified under Standing Order No. 8.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal has held that the relevant Standing Order No. 8 justified the lay off.

facts.text: Tribunal alternatively held common law right to lay-off recognized by s.25C.

anchor.surface_text: In the alternative, the Tribunal thought that even if the lay off was not justified by the relevant clause in the Standing Order, the respondent had a common law right to declare a lay off and this right was recognised by s. 25C of the Act.

facts.text: Tribunal found companies suffered losses, some not declaring dividends for years.

anchor.surface_text: They have suffered losses which are by no means inconsiderable, said the Tribunal, and some of the companies have not been able to declare dividends in time during the last ten years, though others have declared them from year to year.

facts.text: For five companies (Bhubandhar, Doyapore, Western Cachar, Borak, Koyah), lay-off justified only for 21 days, full wages for excess 24 days.

anchor.surface_text: On the whole, the Tribunal thought it necessary to distinguish between the different tea estates with which it was dealing, and having considered their respective individual cases, it came to the conclusion that out of the nine companies, five companies need not have declared lay off for 45 days. ... These five companies are Bhubandhar, Doyapore, Western Cachar, Borak and Koyah.

facts.text: For four companies (Doodputlee Majagram, Scottpore, Tarrapore), lay-off fully justified.

anchor.surface_text: In regard to the remaining four companies, the Tribunal held that the lay off was fully justified, ... The other four companies in respect of which the Tribunal has given no relief to the workmen are Doodputlee Majagram, Scottpore and Tarrapore.

facts.text: Supreme Court held s.25C does not recognize common law right to lay-off.

anchor.surface_text: This question must, in our opinion, be answered in the negative. ... No such common law right can be spelt out from the provisions of s. 25C.

facts.text: Lay-off not justified under Rule 8(a)(i) of Standing Orders.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are satisfied that the Tribunal was in error in holding that the impugned lay off could be justified by Rule 8(a)(i).

facts.text: Financial difficulties not beyond control of management.

anchor.surface_text: we see no justification for the argument that the financial difficulty which is alleged to have confronted the respondent was beyond its control.

facts.text: Operations resumed after lay-off and continued uninterrupted.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, it is clear that at the end of the period of the lay off, all the Cos. started operating their tea gardens and we have been told that the operations have continued uninterrupted ever since.

facts.text: Appeal allowed, full wages awarded for 45 days lay-off to appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is accordingly allowed and the appellants claim for full wages for the 45 days of lay off in respect of the 11 tea gardens is awarded to them.

facts.text: Standing Orders certified under Industrial Employment Standing Orders Act, 1946, came into force in 1950.

anchor.surface_text: the present Standing Orders which were duly certified under the Standing Orders Act came into force in 1950

facts.text: Section 2(kkk) added to ID Act by Amending Act 43 of 1953 on October 24, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: whereas s. 2(kkk) which defines a lay off was added to the Act by the Amending Act 43 of 1953 on the 24th October, 1953.

facts.text: Chartered Bank letter dated April 9, 1959, expressing reluctance to afford financial facilities.

anchor.surface_text: the Tribunal has made a definite finding that though the respondent had produced a letter from the Chartered Bank of the 9th April, 1959 in which the Bank expressed its reluctance to afford financial facilities

facts.text: Some companies unable to pay dividends 1951-1958.

anchor.surface_text: It is true, as Mr. Banerjee has pointed out, that the three Cos. Scottpore, Tarrapore and Doodputalee have not been able to pay dividends between 1951 to 1958
Appeal by special leave from the award dated December 11, 1959, of the Industrial Tribunal, Assam at Gauhati
under s. 10(1)(d) of the Act. The 11 tea estates which are concerned with this dispute were described in Appendix A to the order of reference.

anchor.surface_text: The first question which arises for our decision is whether the Tribunal was justified in holding that s. 25C recognises the companymon law right of the respondent to declare a lay off for reasons other than those specified in the relevant clause of the Standing Order.

holdings.text: Section 25C does not recognise any common law or inherent right of the employer to declare a lay-off; it applies only to lay-offs as defined in s.2(kkk).

anchor.surface_text: This question must, in our opinion, be answered in the negative. When the laying off of the workmen is referred to in s. 25C, it is the laying off as defined by s. 2(kkk), and so, workmen who can claim the benefit of s. 25C must be workmen who are laid off and laid off for reasons contemplated by s. 2(kkk) that is all that s. 25C means. If any case is not covered by the Standing Orders, it will necessarily be governed by the provisions of the Act, and lay off would be permissible only where one or the other of the factors mentioned by s. 2(kkk) is present, and for such lay off compensation would be awarded under s. 25C. Therefore, we do not think that the Tribunal was right in holding that s. 25C recognises the inherent right of the employer to declare lay off for reasons which he may regard as sufficient or satisfactory in that behalf. No such common law right can be spelt out from the provisions of s. 25C.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.25C refers to 'laid off' as defined in s.2(kkk); no provision spells out inherent employer right beyond statutory definition; Standing Orders govern if applicable, otherwise Act's definition.

holdings.text: The lay-off declared by the respondent is not justified under Rule 8(a)(i) of the certified Standing Orders.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are satisfied that the Tribunal was in error in holding that the impugned lay off could be justified by Rule 8(a)(i). Rule 8(a)(iii) which refers to temporary curtailment of production must obviously be read in the light of R. 8(a)(i) and if the case of the present lay off does not fall under R. 8(a)(i), R. 8(a)(iii) would not improve the position.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Financial difficulties/trade depression do not fall within specified causes (fire, breakdown, stoppage of power/supply, etc.) or 'other causes beyond control'; stoppage of supply means materials, not funds; difficulties not proven beyond control as operations resumed post-lay-off.

holdings.text: Certified Standing Orders (from 1950) govern lay-off rights and are not overridden by later definitional provision s.2(kkk) (added 1953), which is not operative.

anchor.surface_text: We are not prepared to accept the argument that in the present case, the respondent can rely on the definition of lay off as prescribed by s. 2(kkk). It will be recalled that the Standing Orders which have been certified under the Standing Orders Act became part of the statutory terms and conditions of service between the industrial employer and his employees. Section 10(1) of the Standing Orders Act provides that the Standing Orders finally certified under this Act shall not, except on agreement between the employer and the workmen, be liable to modification until the expiry of six months from the date on which the Standing Orders or the last modification thereof came into operation. If the Standing Orders thus become the part of the statutory terms and conditions of service, they will govern the relations between the parties unless, of course, it can be shown that any provision of the Act is inconsistent with the said Standing Orders. In that case, it may be permissible to urge that the statutory provision contained in the Act should over-ride the Standing Order which had been certified before the said statutory provision was enacted. Assuming without deciding that s. 2(kkk) may include the trading reasons as suggested by Mr. Banerjee, the definition prescribed by s. 2(kkk) is not a part of the operative provisions of the Act, and so, the argument that there is inconsistency between the definition and the relevant Rule of the Standing Orders does not assist Mr. Banerjee's case. If there had been a provision in the Act specifically providing that an employer would be entitled to lay off his workmen for the reasons prescribed by s. 2(kkk), it might have been another matter. The only provision on which reliance has been placed is contained in s. 25C and that, as we have already seen, merely takes in the definition of lay off inasmuch as it refers to the workmen as laid off and provides the manner in which compensation would be paid to them. An alleged conflict between the definition of lay off and the substantive rule of the Standing Orders would not, therefore, help the respondent to contend that the definition over-rides the statutory conditions as to lay off included in the certified Standing Order. Therefore, we do not think Mr. Banerjee would be entitled to contend that s. 2(kkk) of the Act is wider than the relevant Rule in the Standing Orders and should apply to the facts of this case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Certified SO are statutory conditions of service under Standing Orders Act s.10(1); later definitional s.2(kkk) not operative/inconsistent to override; s.25C merely compensatory, incorporates definition but doesn't authorize lay-off.

holdings.text: Financial difficulties faced by respondent not beyond its control so as to justify lay-off under 'other causes beyond his control' in Rule 8(a)(i).

anchor.surface_text: We are not inclined to accept this argument also. Other causes beyond his control for one thing should be similar to the causes that have preceded even otherwise we see no justification for the argument that the financial difficulty which is alleged to have confronted the respondent was beyond its control.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence (bank letter post-dates lay-off, operations resumed uninterrupted, no proof of complete failure to raise funds, comparative tea estates similarly situated) shows difficulties manageable.

holdings.text: It is not necessary to decide whether 'for any other reason' in s.2(kkk) includes trading reasons (ejusdem generis argument prima facie forceful but left open).

anchor.surface_text: We ought to make it clear that in dealing with this argument, we have not thought it necessary to consider whether the broad and general construction of s. 2(kkk) for which Mr. Banerjee contends is justified. In fact, Mr. Agarwala for the appellants has very strongly urged that the words for any reason found in s. 2(kkk) will not take in the trading considerations. He contends and prima facie with some force that the said words must be construed ejusdem generis with the words that precede them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dispute governed by Standing Orders; no need to construe s.2(kkk) scope as case doesn't turn on it.

holdings.text: Lay-off unjustified in all 11 tea estates; appellants entitled to full wages for 45 days.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we reverse the finding of the Tribunal that the lay off declared by the respondent for 45 days in 1959 was justified. That being so, it is unnecessary to consider the individual cases of the nine respective companies, because whatever may have been their respective financial position, under the relevant Rule they could not validly declare a lay off at all, nor could they have declared the lay off in exercise of their alleged common law right. The questions referred to the Tribunal must, therefore, be answered in favour of the appellants. The appeal is accordingly allowed and the appellants claim for full wages for the 45 days of lay off in respect of the 11 tea gardens is awarded to them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of prior holdings: no justification under SO, no common law right, no override by s.2(kkk); applies uniformly regardless of individual finances.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we reverse the finding of the Tribunal that the lay off declared by the respondent for 45 days in 1959 was justified. That being so, it is unnecessary to consider the individual cases of the nine respective companypanies, because whatever may have been their respective financial -position, under the relevant Rule they companyld number validly declare a lay off at all, nor companyld they have declared the lay off in exercise of their alleged companymon law right. The questions referred to the Tribunal must, therefore, be answered in favour of the appellants. The appeal is accordingly allowed and the appellants claim for full wages for the 45 days of lay off in respect of the 11 tea gardens is awarded to them.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; Tribunal's award reversed; full wages awarded to appellants (workmen) for the entire 45 days of lay-off in respect of all 11 tea gardens
directions: Reverse the finding of the Tribunal that the lay-off was justified
Answer the questions referred to the Tribunal in favour of the appellants
Award full wages for 45 days lay-off to appellants for 11 tea gardens

anchor.surface_text: This question must, in our opinion, be answered in the negative. When the laying off of the workmen is referred to in s. 25C, it is the laying off as defined by s. 2(kkk), and so, workmen who can claim the benefit of s. 25C must be workmen who are laid off and laid off for reasons contemplated by s. 2(kkk) that is all that s. 25C means. If any case is not covered by the Standing Orders, it will necessarily be governed by the provisions of the Act, and lay off would be permissible only where one or the other of the factors mentioned by s. 2(kkk) is present, and for such lay off compensation would be awarded under s. 25C. Therefore, we do not think that the Tribunal was right in holding that s. 25C recognises the inherent right of the employer to declare lay off for reasons which he may regard as sufficient or satisfactory in that behalf. No such common law right can be spelt out from the provisions of s. 25C.

In the result, we reverse the finding of the Tribunal that the lay off declared by the respondent for 45 days in 1959 was justified. That being so, it is unnecessary to consider the individual cases of the nine respective companypanies, because whatever may have been their respective financial -position, under the relevant Rule they companyld number validly declare a lay off at all, nor companyld they have declared the lay off in exercise of their alleged companymon law right. The questions referred to the Tribunal must, therefore, be answered in favour of the appellants. The appeal is accordingly allowed and the appellants claim for full wages for the 45 days of lay off in respect of the 11 tea gardens is awarded to them.

edges.explanation: Holding h2 directly states that the lay-off is not justified under Rule 8(a)(i) of the certified Standing Orders, addressing issue i2 on justification under certified Rule 8.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are satisfied that the Tribunal was in error in holding that the impugned lay off could be justified by Rule 8(a)(i). Rule 8(a)(iii) which refers to temporary curtailment of production must obviously be read in the light of R. 8(a)(i) and if the case of the present lay off does not fall under R. 8(a)(i), R. 8(a)(iii) would not improve the position.

In the result, we reverse the finding of the Tribunal that the lay off declared by the respondent for 45 days in 1959 was justified. That being so, it is unnecessary to consider the individual cases of the nine respective companypanies, because whatever may have been their respective financial -position, under the relevant Rule they companyld number validly declare a lay off at all, nor companyld they have declared the lay off in exercise of their alleged companymon law right. The questions referred to the Tribunal must, therefore, be answered in favour of the appellants. The appeal is accordingly allowed and the appellants claim for full wages for the 45 days of lay off in respect of the 11 tea gardens is awarded to them.

anchor.surface_text: We are not prepared to accept the argument that in the present case, the respondent can rely on the definition of lay off as prescribed by s. 2(kkk). It will be recalled that the Standing Orders which have been certified under the Standing Orders Act became part of the statutory terms and conditions of service between the industrial employer and his employees. Section 10(1) of the Standing Orders Act provides that the Standing Orders finally certified under this Act shall not, except on agreement between the employer and the workmen, be liable to modification until the expiry of six months from the date on which the Standing Orders or the last modification thereof came into operation. If the Standing Orders thus become the part of the statutory terms and conditions of service, they will govern the relations between the parties unless, of course, it can be shown that any provision of the Act is inconsistent with the said Standing Orders. In that case, it may be permissible to urge that the statutory provision contained in the Act should over-ride the Standing Order which had been certified before the said statutory provision was enacted. Assuming without deciding that s. 2(kkk) may include the trading reasons as suggested by Mr. Banerjee, the definition prescribed by s. 2(kkk) is not a part of the operative provisions of the Act, and so, the argument that there is inconsistency between the definition and the relevant Rule of the Standing Orders does not assist Mr. Banerjee's case. If there had been a provision in the Act specifically providing that an employer would be entitled to lay off his workmen for the reasons prescribed by s. 2(kkk), it might have been another matter. The only provision on which reliance has been placed is contained in s. 25C and that, as we have already seen, merely takes in the definition of lay off inasmuch as it refers to the workmen as laid off and provides the manner in which compensation would be paid to them. An alleged conflict between the definition of lay off and the substantive rule of the Standing Orders would not, therefore, help the respondent to contend that the definition over-rides the statutory conditions as to lay off included in the certified Standing Order. Therefore, we do not think Mr. Banerjee would be entitled to contend that s. 2(kkk) of the Act is wider than the relevant Rule in the Standing Orders and should apply to the facts of this case.

In the result, we reverse the finding of the Tribunal that the lay off declared by the respondent for 45 days in 1959 was justified. That being so, it is unnecessary to consider the individual cases of the nine respective companypanies, because whatever may have been their respective financial -position, under the relevant Rule they companyld number validly declare a lay off at all, nor companyld they have declared the lay off in exercise of their alleged companymon law right. The questions referred to the Tribunal must, therefore, be answered in favour of the appellants. The appeal is accordingly allowed and the appellants claim for full wages for the 45 days of lay off in respect of the 11 tea gardens is awarded to them.

anchor.surface_text: We ought to make it clear that in dealing with this argument, we have not thought it necessary to consider whether the broad and general construction of s. 2(kkk) for which Mr. Banerjee contends is justified. In fact, Mr. Agarwala for the appellants has very strongly urged that the words for any reason found in s. 2(kkk) will not take in the trading considerations. He contends and prima facie with some force that the said words must be construed ejusdem generis with the words that precede them.

In the result, we reverse the finding of the Tribunal that the lay off declared by the respondent for 45 days in 1959 was justified. That being so, it is unnecessary to consider the individual cases of the nine respective companypanies, because whatever may have been their respective financial -position, under the relevant Rule they companyld number validly declare a lay off at all, nor companyld they have declared the lay off in exercise of their alleged companymon law right. The questions referred to the Tribunal must, therefore, be answered in favour of the appellants. The appeal is accordingly allowed and the appellants claim for full wages for the 45 days of lay off in respect of the 11 tea gardens is awarded to them.
